title: O Week ends with gang members fighting in Hamilton street
text:
O Week ends with gang members fighting in Hamilton street KELSEY WILKIE Last updated 20:52, February 27 2017 CHRISTEL YARDLEY/FAIRFAX NZ 
Despite the incident occurring at the end of O Week celebrations, police say students had nothing to do with the brawl. 
Mayhem in Hamilton's central city in the early hours on Sunday was a one-off, police say. 
A disgruntled gang member who was kicked out of The Hood nightclub was allegedly the instigator of multiple brawls that saw police and nightclub security form a skirmish line to get the crowd under control, The Lawrenson Group chief executive John Lawrenson said. 
It was about 2.30am on Sunday when the incident kicked off in Victoria St, he said. 
"After they had been removed they went and basically found their posse and then that group basically came and caused a lot of problems." 
He said at first security staff were targeted and then some people started fights because they "thought it was funny". 
"I haven't seen anything like that in seven years. The last time I saw the police form a skirmish line like that was seven years ago, it was similar issues â€¦ it was an absolute mess." 
He said there were about 20-30 Lawrenson Group staff who worked with police to clear the street by 3am. 
"This is not an alcohol-related harm incident, this is a gang violence issue." 
Inspector Karen Henrikson said it was the first time in years she had seen any incident of this scale in central Hamilton. 
There were 42 arrests during the night in the CBD. 
She was unsure how many of those arrests had been made earlier in the night but says it was higher than police were expecting. 
She was reluctant to call it a brawl. She said it was "pockets of disorder". 
"This one-off incident is really disappointing. We will certainly be following up with those involved, unravelling what has happened and initiate other efforts to reduce any opportunity for this to happen again." 
Despite the incident occurring at the end of O Week celebrations, she said it had nothing to do with the event. 
In March 2014, there were 86 reported offences in the city during O Week. Since then there has been an effort to reduce the number of offences. 
Police had increased presence in the CBD to manage crowds. 
There was also a safe zone on Victoria St to assist. 
The safe zone was a multi-agency initiative, it was brightly lit and manned by police, paramedics and Waikato Student Union volunteers. It was set up by the city's CBD Safety Comes First group to help curb the disorder that spikes during O Week. 
"We will be debriefing the incident to determine if we could have done things better." - Stuff
